description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4cb73","text":"This protocol describes how to replenish the frozen \"fossil\" record of the E. coli Long-Term Evolution Experiment (LTEE) by making copies of freezer stocks. Different methods are used to copy population samples versus clonal samples. For the former, the goal is to make a representative copy that maintains the genetic diversity that is present in the population. For the latter, the goal is to make a copy of a homogeneous cell population without allowing it to evolve new mutations.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":74,"length":9},{"style":"italic","offset":192,"length":18},{"style":"italic","offset":218,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9jfop","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2ljj","text":"The culture media and supplies needed for this protocol are described here:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dat1u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1e7k2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"protocols","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"id":74233,"title":"LTEE Media Recipes ","title_html":"LTEE Media Recipes ","load_collapsed":true,"uri":"ltee-media-recipes-ckqzuvx6","image":{"source":"https://content.protocols.io/files/j7dtbqmhf.jpg","webp_source":null,"placeholder":"https://content.protocols.io/files/j7dtbqmhf.jpg","webp_placeholder":null},"creator":{"name":"Jeffrey E Barrick","affiliation":"The University of Texas at Austin","affiliation_url":"","username":"jeffrey-e-barrick","link":"https://barricklab.org","image":{"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/j7eybqmhf.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/j7eybqmhf.jpg","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/j7exbqmhf.webp"}},"stats":{"number_of_steps":37},"type_id":1,"guid":"E0325ED0F44D11ED83670F58EF722049"}}}}

It may not do so perfectly (especially for Cit+ populations), but it should work to reasonably preserve the representative genetic diversity within the population.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

A small glass vial (0.5 dram) can be filled with   each, while large glass vials (2 dram) can be filled with   each. Be careful not to overfill the vials, or they can break as the contents freeze and expand.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":4,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":9,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":229,"length":1},{"key":3,"offset":289,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"c998h","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"B2EB4B70F36311EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"1":{"type":"concentration","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"concentration":"80","error_concentration":false,"guid":"BCE3A1E0F36311EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":206}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"1.25","error":false,"guid":"E0C21100F36311EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}},"3":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"6","error":false,"guid":"EA0C4D20F36311EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"10fnp","text":"Use this procedure to make copies of samples of clonal isolates from the LTEE.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6bm2q","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7vaeb","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3iqf9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":41,"offset":488,"style":"italic"}],"key":"49jgo","text":"Clonal isolates were obtained by picking single colonies from agar plates after multiple rounds of purification by streaking. They should consequently have minimal genetic diversity. (Ideally, they should have no genetic diversity, but mutations occur during the growth of colonies, so low frequencies of genetic variants are unavoidable.) Unlike with the above case of copying samples of mixed populations, the principal concern with copying clonal samples is minimize the potential for further evolution caused by new mutations.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ecc8p","text":"Fill each flask with   ml o","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":21,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3t9tg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"9.88","error":false,"guid":"8AE9F220F35911EDA792651F01B860E0","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":2}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"frlth","text":"Thoroughly vortex each test tube three times before using a micropipettor to transfer   from it into one of the new flasks filled with DM25.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":135,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":86,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"671o6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"amount":"100","error":false,"guid":"58D72500F36311EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"93o8m","text":"Use this procedure to make copies of archived population samples from the LTEE that are as close as possible to exact copies of the original samples. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"70oqq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a8pu","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"43fgr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":148,"style":"italic"},{"length":33,"offset":673,"style":"italic"},{"length":34,"offset":760,"style":"italic"},{"length":41,"offset":806,"style":"italic"},{"length":8,"offset":198,"style":"bold"}],"key":"44gje","text":"Strictly speaking, making an exact copy of a bacterial population is impossible. Stored samples are frozen with glycerol as a cryoprotectant (which E. coli cells can metabolize), and are revived in DM1000. Thus, a frozen population that is being revived is exposed to a resource environment that contains both glycerol and a far higher glucose concentration than is found in DM25. As these conditions are very different than those the population experienced during the LTEE prior to archiving, outgrowth during revival is an unavoidable perturbation. However, this procedure has been designed to ameliorate and reduce the effects of this perturbation so as to maintain the representative genetic diversity within the population sample, minimize changes in the frequencies of different genotypes, and avoid further evolution caused by new mutations. ","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"esa1e","text":"Prepare an autoclaved 50-mL Erlenmeyer flask capped with a 20-mL beaker for each sample that will be revived, plus a blank. Fill each flask with   of DM1000. Scrape   –   of frozen culture from the freezer vial using a pipette tip attached to a pipettor and use it to inoculate the flask. The important point in this step is to inoculate with enough cells that it is unlikely that a low frequency genetic variant in the stock might be overrepresented in the inoculum. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"94q5k","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"2","error":false,"guid":"C8F7AF90F36711EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"},"1":{"data":{"amount":"10","error":false,"guid":"CFBA2F60F36711EDB87C8D5A4500C4DA","id":0,"label":"","scientificNotation":false,"unit":1},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"amount"}}}}}}
